visual_elements.description: A table defining different types of 'Grade' based on 'When measuring', 'Use', 'Which is defined as', and 'Illus.'. It has four columns and four rows (including header).

Figure 45, titled 'Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%'. It shows two houses built on a sloped terrain. Dashed lines indicate '30' above existing grade' and '30' above finished' grade. Arrows point to 'Height' measurements for each house, extending from the ground to the roof peak. The ground is depicted with cross-hatching for existing grade (before fill) and a solid line for finished grade. A text box explains that 'The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope'.

Figure 44, titled 'Existing vs. Finished grade'. It shows a cross-section of a house with its foundation. The ground is depicted with cross-hatching. A dashed line indicates 'Existing grade (before fill)' and a solid line indicates 'Finished grade (after fill)'. An arrow points from the 'Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure' to a specific point on the existing grade line near the foundation. Another vertical arrow indicates 'Height: measured to top of roof material of the highest peak'.

Figure 46, titled 'Comparison of different grades'. It is a line chart with a grid, showing four diagonal lines representing different slopes. The lines are labeled with ratios and percentages: '1:10 10%', '3:10 33%', '5:10 50%', and '10:10 100%'. The lines originate from the bottom right corner and extend upwards and to the left.

additional_notes: Page number '47' is present at the bottom right corner.
The word 'materoal' in 'Height: measured to top of roof materoal of the highest peak' in Fig 44 appears to be a typo and should likely be 'material'.
